title: China Eximbank provides a $10 million USD export seller’s credit for the 24 MW Khadori Hydropower Station Project (Linked to Project ID#67744 and #42915)
description: On March 27, 2001, the Export-Import Bank of China issued a pair of export seller’s credits to Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of Sichuan Electric Power Import and Export Corporation (SEPC) (a 54% ownership stake), Hainan S.I.T Enterprise (a 39% ownership stake), and Peri Ltd. (a 7% ownership stake) — for the 24 MW Khadori Hydropower Station Project: a $10 million USD export seller’s credit (captured by Project ID#67739) and a RMB 78 million export seller’s credit (captured by Project ID#67744). Both of these credits carried maturity periods of 8 years, and an interest rate greater than 0%. The People's Insurance Company of China provided overseas investment insurance for the project. The total cost of the project was approximately $34 million USD.  The purpose of this project was to construct a 24-megawatt hydroelectric power plant located at the confluence of the Alazani river and the Samkura river in Pankisi Valley. The power station was expected to annually generate 140 million kilowatt (kV) hours on average. At the time, Georgia had an electricity shortage issue, which the project sought to rectify. The project also sought to capitalize on potentially exporting power to Turkey, which also faces power shortages, in the future. The project was implemented on a Build-Own-Operate (BOO) basis and financed with a mix of debt and equity. As specified in a contract with the Georgian Government, SEPC would operate the station for 25 years and receive the financial returns from the station's power generation. If Khadori turned out to be profitable after the expiration of the 25-year contract period, SEPC would be given the choice to retain its ownership of it. The equity investment by SEPC that was made in the project, $34 million USD, is captured by linked project ID#42915.  Sichuan Electric Power Import and Export Corporation (SEPC) — a wholly-owned subsidiary of the State Grid Corporation of China — was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. also helped implement the project. Peri Ltd. was also active in implementation. The majority of the equipment for the power station came from China, including the generator sets and 35 kilometers of 110 kV transmission and transformation lines. Dongfang Electric Corporation provided the plant's hydroelectric generators. PowerChina Construction Group Chengdu Survey and Design Research Institute Co., Ltd. designed the power station. Sichuan Ertan International Engineering Consulting Co., Ltd. (ETI) provided project supervision. Sinohydro Bureau 10 Co., Ltd. was responsible for the installation of mechanical and electrical equipment. Hunan Sunny Hydropower Equipment Corporation (SHPE) provided 2x2700 kW Francis Turbine generator units.  The project began implementation on February 4, 2001, with a construction period of two years. The project completed and the hydropower station was connected to the Georgian power grid and put into commercial operation by then-President of Georgia Mikheil Saakashvili on November 20, 2004. Implementation had been slowed because of militant activity and by the new government of Georgia (which had been brought to power by the 2003 Rose Revolution), which refused to recognize an agreement on project implementation that the past government had made with Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. The project was put into full operation on February 23, 2006. The power station has 60 employees; 50 are Georgian and 10 are Chinese.  This was reportedly China Eximbank's first export seller's credit project in the West. It also described as the first power station and the first large-scale foreign investment in Georgia since its independence.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Khadori II HPP Project. The Chinese title of the project is 卡杜里水电站.2. Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. was established in 1999 as a project company responsible for financing, designing, constructing and operating the 24 MW Khadori Hydropower Station for a 25-year period. In 2004, Hainan S.I.T Enterprise sold its shares in the company to Sichuan Electric Power Import and Export Corporation and the new ownership structure of Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. was as follows: SEPC (93% ownership stake) and Peri Ltd. (7% ownership stake). SEPC is a state-owned Chinese enterprise and Peri Ltd. is a private Georgian enterprise. These two companies subsequently brought a dispute to Tbilisi City Court, which resulted in the court imposing a lien on the 93% ownership stake of SEPC in Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd.  Then, on October 1, 2013, the parties to the dispute agreed that Peri Ltd. would withdraw its lawsuit and demand removal of the lien, while SEPC would purchase Peri Ltd.’s 7% ownership stake in Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. for $1.9 million USD. After meeting these requirements, SEPC pledged to give Peri Ltd. the right to transmit electricity generated by the 24 MW Khadori Hydropower Station (or ’Khadori 2 HPP’) through its own power transmission line for a period of 10 years and at a preferential rate (see pg.4 of 'ENERGY PROJECTS AND CORRUPTION IN GEORGIA').
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides a $10 million USD export seller’s credit for the 24 MW Khadori Hydropower Station Project (Linked to Project ID#67744 and #42915)

# Description
On March 27, 2001, the Export-Import Bank of China issued a pair of export seller’s credits to Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of Sichuan Electric Power Import and Export Corporation (SEPC) (a 54% ownership stake), Hainan S.I.T Enterprise (a 39% ownership stake), and Peri Ltd. (a 7% ownership stake) — for the 24 MW Khadori Hydropower Station Project: a $10 million USD export seller’s credit (captured by Project ID#67739) and a RMB 78 million export seller’s credit (captured by Project ID#67744). Both of these credits carried maturity periods of 8 years, and an interest rate greater than 0%. The People's Insurance Company of China provided overseas investment insurance for the project. The total cost of the project was approximately $34 million USD.  The purpose of this project was to construct a 24-megawatt hydroelectric power plant located at the confluence of the Alazani river and the Samkura river in Pankisi Valley. The power station was expected to annually generate 140 million kilowatt (kV) hours on average. At the time, Georgia had an electricity shortage issue, which the project sought to rectify. The project also sought to capitalize on potentially exporting power to Turkey, which also faces power shortages, in the future. The project was implemented on a Build-Own-Operate (BOO) basis and financed with a mix of debt and equity. As specified in a contract with the Georgian Government, SEPC would operate the station for 25 years and receive the financial returns from the station's power generation. If Khadori turned out to be profitable after the expiration of the 25-year contract period, SEPC would be given the choice to retain its ownership of it. The equity investment by SEPC that was made in the project, $34 million USD, is captured by linked project ID#42915.  Sichuan Electric Power Import and Export Corporation (SEPC) — a wholly-owned subsidiary of the State Grid Corporation of China — was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. also helped implement the project. Peri Ltd. was also active in implementation. The majority of the equipment for the power station came from China, including the generator sets and 35 kilometers of 110 kV transmission and transformation lines. Dongfang Electric Corporation provided the plant's hydroelectric generators. PowerChina Construction Group Chengdu Survey and Design Research Institute Co., Ltd. designed the power station. Sichuan Ertan International Engineering Consulting Co., Ltd. (ETI) provided project supervision. Sinohydro Bureau 10 Co., Ltd. was responsible for the installation of mechanical and electrical equipment. Hunan Sunny Hydropower Equipment Corporation (SHPE) provided 2x2700 kW Francis Turbine generator units.  The project began implementation on February 4, 2001, with a construction period of two years. The project completed and the hydropower station was connected to the Georgian power grid and put into commercial operation by then-President of Georgia Mikheil Saakashvili on November 20, 2004. Implementation had been slowed because of militant activity and by the new government of Georgia (which had been brought to power by the 2003 Rose Revolution), which refused to recognize an agreement on project implementation that the past government had made with Eastern Energy Corporation Ltd. The project was put into full operation on February 23, 2006. The power station has 60 employees; 50 are Georgian and 10 are Chinese.  This was reportedly China Eximbank's first export seller's credit project in the West. It also described as the first power station and the first large-scale foreign investment in Georgia since its independence.
justification: Primary purpose is hydroelectric power generation, a renewable energy source
evidence: 24 MW hydroelectric power plant, expected to generate 140 million kWh annually, renewable energy focus

title: Chinese Government donates fireworks for first anniversary of NPP administration celebration in Ghana
description: In January 2001, the Chinese Government donated 90 cartons of fireworks to the Government Ghana for the first anniversary celebrations of the NPP administration. The Chinese Ambassador Lu Yongshou presented the donation to Jake Obetsebi-Lamptey, Minister of Information and Presidential Affairs.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government donates fireworks for first anniversary of NPP administration celebration in Ghana

# Description
In January 2001, the Chinese Government donated 90 cartons of fireworks to the Government Ghana for the first anniversary celebrations of the NPP administration. The Chinese Ambassador Lu Yongshou presented the donation to Jake Obetsebi-Lamptey, Minister of Information and Presidential Affairs.
justification: Project is a donation for a celebration event with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Fireworks donation for government anniversary celebration

title: Chinese Government cancels $74.8 million of Government of Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations
description: On August 28, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guinea signed a debt exemption protocol agreement (中华人民共和国政府和几内亚共和国政府关于免除几内亚政府债务的议定书). Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to cancel the Government of Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations related to 8 interest-free loans. The Government of Guinea contracted these loans between 1962 and 1992 and all of the loans matured on or before December 31, 1999. The value of these outstanding debt obligations was RMB 60 million (approximately $31,138,884.64), GBP 13,229,856.64 (approximately $21,432,367.75) and $22,310,525.37. Therefore, the aggregate value of these outstanding debt obligations was approximately $74,881,777.76.   The exempted repayment obligations include: (1) an interest-free loan worth 22,500,000 rubles (or $20,310,525.37) that was contracted on September 13, 1960 (2) an interest-free loan worth GBP 9,333,600 that was contracted on November 16, 1966 (3) an interest-free trade loan worth GBP 1,750,050 that was contracted on November 16, 1966  (4) an interest-free loan worth GBP 120,900 that was contracted on August 26, 1968, for a cultural project (5) an interest-free trade loan worth GBP 2,100,000 that was contracted on February 28, 1969 (6) an interest-free loan worth RMB 50 million (converted to $29,325,513.2 at the average annual exchange rate of RMB and US dollars when the repayment period first began) that was contracted on October 9, 1969 (7) an interest-free loan worth RMB 10 million (converted to $1,813,371.44 at the average annual exchange rate of RMB and US dollars when the repayment period first began) that was contracted on October 9, 1969 (8) an interest-free $2 million loan contracted on November 27, 1992
staff_comments: 1. These canceled debts are not included in the dataset of Chinese debt cancellations and restructurings released by SAIS-CARI in 2020. 2. This project record is not coded as an umbrella record because all 8 of the loans forgiven were contracted prior to 2000, so there is no risk for double-counting.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels $74.8 million of Government of Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations

# Description
On August 28, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guinea signed a debt exemption protocol agreement (中华人民共和国政府和几内亚共和国政府关于免除几内亚政府债务的议定书). Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to cancel the Government of Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations related to 8 interest-free loans. The Government of Guinea contracted these loans between 1962 and 1992 and all of the loans matured on or before December 31, 1999. The value of these outstanding debt obligations was RMB 60 million (approximately $31,138,884.64), GBP 13,229,856.64 (approximately $21,432,367.75) and $22,310,525.37. Therefore, the aggregate value of these outstanding debt obligations was approximately $74,881,777.76.   The exempted repayment obligations include: (1) an interest-free loan worth 22,500,000 rubles (or $20,310,525.37) that was contracted on September 13, 1960 (2) an interest-free loan worth GBP 9,333,600 that was contracted on November 16, 1966 (3) an interest-free trade loan worth GBP 1,750,050 that was contracted on November 16, 1966  (4) an interest-free loan worth GBP 120,900 that was contracted on August 26, 1968, for a cultural project (5) an interest-free trade loan worth GBP 2,100,000 that was contracted on February 28, 1969 (6) an interest-free loan worth RMB 50 million (converted to $29,325,513.2 at the average annual exchange rate of RMB and US dollars when the repayment period first began) that was contracted on October 9, 1969 (7) an interest-free loan worth RMB 10 million (converted to $1,813,371.44 at the average annual exchange rate of RMB and US dollars when the repayment period first began) that was contracted on October 9, 1969 (8) an interest-free $2 million loan contracted on November 27, 1992
justification: Debt cancellation agreement without specific environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Debt exemption protocol agreement, financial restructuring with no direct environmental impact

title: Chinese Government cancels RMB 62.7 million of Government of Guinea-Bissau’s outstanding debt obligations
description: On June 29, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guinea-Bissau signed a debt exemption protocol agreement. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to cancel the Government of Guinea-Bissau’s outstanding debt obligations related to 6 interest-free loans. The Government of Guinea-Bissau contracted these loans between 1975 and 1987 and all of the loans matured on or before December 31, 1999. The aggregate value of these outstanding debt obligations was RMB 62,757,069.  The exempted repayment obligations include (1) an interest-free loan worth RMB 30 million that was contracted on July 9, 1975; (2) an interest-free commodity loan worth RMB 3 million that was contracted on August 14th, 1982; (3) an interest-free loan worth RMB 160,000 that was contracted on November 7, 1983; (4) an interest-free loan worth RMB 4,600,000 that was contracted on October 18, 1985; (5) an interest-free loan worth RMB 10 million that was contracted on May 19, 1986; and (6) an interest-free loan worth RMB 15 million that was contracted on November 15, 1987.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels RMB 62.7 million of Government of Guinea-Bissau’s outstanding debt obligations

# Description
On June 29, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guinea-Bissau signed a debt exemption protocol agreement. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to cancel the Government of Guinea-Bissau’s outstanding debt obligations related to 6 interest-free loans. The Government of Guinea-Bissau contracted these loans between 1975 and 1987 and all of the loans matured on or before December 31, 1999. The aggregate value of these outstanding debt obligations was RMB 62,757,069.  The exempted repayment obligations include (1) an interest-free loan worth RMB 30 million that was contracted on July 9, 1975; (2) an interest-free commodity loan worth RMB 3 million that was contracted on August 14th, 1982; (3) an interest-free loan worth RMB 160,000 that was contracted on November 7, 1983; (4) an interest-free loan worth RMB 4,600,000 that was contracted on October 18, 1985; (5) an interest-free loan worth RMB 10 million that was contracted on May 19, 1986; and (6) an interest-free loan worth RMB 15 million that was contracted on November 15, 1987.
justification: Debt cancellation is a financial service with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt exemption protocol agreement, cancellation of interest-free loans

title: Chinese Government sends 5th medical team to Guyana
description: On November 2, 2001, the Chinese Government signed an exchange of letters committing to dispatch the 5th medical team to Guyana. The 15 members worked at the Georgetown Public Hospital and Linden Hospital Complex between August 2002 and August 2004.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government sends 5th medical team to Guyana

# Description
On November 2, 2001, the Chinese Government signed an exchange of letters committing to dispatch the 5th medical team to Guyana. The 15 members worked at the Georgetown Public Hospital and Linden Hospital Complex between August 2002 and August 2004.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: China sent seismologists to India to help monitor aftershocks
description: China sent nine seismologists to India to help monitor the frequency of aftershocks. The team consists of nine experts in earthquake forecasting and monitoring.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China sent seismologists to India to help monitor aftershocks

# Description
China sent nine seismologists to India to help monitor the frequency of aftershocks. The team consists of nine experts in earthquake forecasting and monitoring.
justification: Project focuses on emergency response and scientific collaboration without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Seismologists sent for earthquake monitoring, humanitarian/scientific focus

title: China donates earthquake relief materials worth 5 million RMB to Gujarat, India
description: Following a devastating earthquake in India on January 26, 2001, the Government of China quickly sent relief materials worth 5 million RMB ($604,887 USD) to Gujarat. Specifically, China sent 10,700 dozens of zinc oxide adhesive plaster, 26,000 dozen bandages, 3,300 rolls of absorbent cotton wool, 20,000 pieces of acrylic blankets, and 2,000 tents. These goods were delivered on February 4, 2001.   The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #2836 and reports it as completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates earthquake relief materials worth 5 million RMB to Gujarat, India

# Description
Following a devastating earthquake in India on January 26, 2001, the Government of China quickly sent relief materials worth 5 million RMB ($604,887 USD) to Gujarat. Specifically, China sent 10,700 dozens of zinc oxide adhesive plaster, 26,000 dozen bandages, 3,300 rolls of absorbent cotton wool, 20,000 pieces of acrylic blankets, and 2,000 tents. These goods were delivered on February 4, 2001.   The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #2836 and reports it as completed.
justification: Project involves humanitarian aid and emergency relief materials without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Earthquake relief materials including medical supplies, blankets, and tents

title: China sent medical team to Gujarat, India for earthquake relief
description: On February 1, 2001, a Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs official announced that the Chinese government had decided to send a medical rescue team to Gujarat, India following the January 26, 2001 earthquake. The duration of the team's stay and the value of this project is unknown.   The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #2806 and reports it as completed.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant to support Afghan refugees living in Iran
description: On November 27, 2001, the Chinese Government announced that it was ready to provide assistance to Afghan refugees in Iran through working with the Iranian government. As of December 2001, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Zhang Qiyue announced that it had been providing relief goods and materials to Afghan refugees in Iran, and would continue to do so.   In November 2001, the Chinese Government sent 39 trucks of relief supplies to Afghan refugees in Iran. Also, an official report on 'China's Relationship with United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)' notes that the Chinese Government had donated relief goods and materials to Afghan refugees in Iran (worth RMB 5 million).
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant to support Afghan refugees living in Iran

# Description
On November 27, 2001, the Chinese Government announced that it was ready to provide assistance to Afghan refugees in Iran through working with the Iranian government. As of December 2001, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Zhang Qiyue announced that it had been providing relief goods and materials to Afghan refugees in Iran, and would continue to do so.   In November 2001, the Chinese Government sent 39 trucks of relief supplies to Afghan refugees in Iran. Also, an official report on 'China's Relationship with United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)' notes that the Chinese Government had donated relief goods and materials to Afghan refugees in Iran (worth RMB 5 million).
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid and refugee support without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Provision of relief goods and materials to Afghan refugees, humanitarian focus
